MgO/SiO2 catalysts prepared by wet-kneading with various compositions were applied to directly convert ethanol to 1,3-butadiene. The MgO/SiO2 molar ratio significantly affected the structural, textural, and surface properties of the catalysts, leading to different activities toward ethanol conversion. At low MgO loading (51 mol %), magnesium silicate is formed on the amorphous silica surface, resulting in a higher activity for ethanol dehydration to ethylene. Increasing the MgO loading, crystalline magnesium oxide is formed in addition to the magnesium silicate, producing strong basic sites capable of increasing the ethanol conversion to 1,3-butadiene. Interestingly, for the mixed oxides prepared herein, a linear correlation was found between the forward reaction rate for 1,3-butadiene formation as a function of the reaction rate for acetaldehyde and ethylene. This behavior suggests a predominance of the Prins condensation mechanism. Therefore, the paired arrangement and the strength of the acid-basic conjugate sites of these catalysts must be determinant for the dehydrogenation and dehydration of ethanol and the condensation of the respective intermediates acetaldehyde and ethylene to form 1,3-butadiene. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bioethanol 1,3-butadiene Biomass conversion Heterogeneous catalysis Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Besides its use as biofuel, ethanol can also find application as a biorenewable source of carbon for producing chemicals [1,2]. Brazil, the second-largest bioethanol producer, has historically led efforts to convert ethanol into chemicals [2,3] The most mature technologies are the production of ethylene and acetic acid, although 1,3-butadiene (BD) from bioethanol has been produced commercially [2]. BD is an important chemical intermediate and monomer for the production of synthetic rubber and other polymers, such as Styrene-Butadiene Rubber (SBR), Polybutadiene Rubber (PBR), and neoprene [1,2]. Its production from ethanol can be performed by the one-step Lebedev process or the two-step Ostromisslensky process, the former the one with higher potential for large-scale application [3]. Two main mechanisms have been proposed for the Lebedev process: the aldol condensation mechanism (Fig. 1 A), which involves ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde followed by Aldol condensation [4,5], while the Prins condensation (Fig. 1B), which involves condensation between acetaldehyde and ethylene, derived from the ethanol dehydrogenation and dehydration, respectively [6]. In both mechanisms, basic sites catalyze most steps, although acidic sites are needed to promote dehydration. Therefore, bifunctional Acid/Base catalysts are typically required to promote ethanol conversion into BD [2]. Due to its bifunctionality, the mixed oxide MgO/SiO2 is a popular catalyst for ethanol conversion in BD [1,7,8]. The ratio between the oxides and the preparation method have been shown to play a major role in catalytic activity. A comparative study has shown that MgO/SiO2 prepared by wet-kneading presents higher BD yields compared to those synthesized by sol-gel or incipient wetness impregnation [7]. However, there is no consensus on the optimal MgO/SiO2 ratio and, using wet-kneading, the best BD yields were claimed to be obtained at a MgO/SiO2 molar ratio of 85/15 [9], 65/35 [7], or 50/50 (when dopped with 0.1 % of Na or K) [10]. The mechanism for ethanol conversion to BD has been studied for MgO/SiO2; however, there is no consensus. For instance, in situ DRIFTS measurements combined with DFT calculations indicated that intermediates of the Aldol condensation mechanism (Fig. 1A) indeed participate in the reaction [11,12]. In this case, weak basic sites would be responsible for ethanol dehydrogenation, the strong basic sites promote Aldol condensation and MPV reduction, and the stronger acidic sites catalyze acetaldol and crotyl alcohol dehydration reactions [11,12]. Contrarily, a DFT study pointed out that the Prins mechanism for C-C bond formation is thermodynamically more favorable than the Aldol C-C coupling step, with a calculated barrier of 10 kcal mol−1 lower than ethanol dehydrogenation [13], which means that the Prins mechanism could parallelly occur in these catalysts. Herein, MgO/SiO2 prepared by wet-kneading using different MgO/SiO2 molar ratios were characterized as regards their structures and studied on the direct conversion of ethanol to BD. The catalytic studies provided important evidence on the preferential reaction pathway. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis of MgOH and SiO2 by precipitation The syntheses of MgOH and SiO2 were carried out in a typical methodology described elsewhere [14]. MgOH: To a solution of 128.0 g of magnesium nitrate hexahydrate [Mg(NO3)2‧6H2O] in 200.0 mL of water, it was slowly added 50.0 mL of 14 % ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH), and the mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The resulting solid was filtered off, washed abundantly with distilled water, and dried at 80°C for 15 h. To produce pure MgO, the solid was calcined under a flow of air (100 mL min−1) at 500°C (2°C min−1) for 4 h. SiO2 : 6.25 mL of nitric acid (HNO3) were added to a solution of 25.0 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and 75.0 mL of ethanol. The solution was homogenized for 5 min, followed by the sequential addition of 25.0 mL of 14 % ammonium hydroxide and 25.0 mL of ethanol. The resulting solid was filtered off, washed abundantly with distilled water, and dried at 80°C for 15 h. To produce pure SiO2, the solid was calcined under a flow of air (100 mL min−1) at 500°C (2°C min−1) for 4 h. 2.2 Synthesis of MgO/SiO2 mixed oxide by wet-kneading MgO/SiO2 mixed oxides were synthesized with uncalcined MgOH, and SiO2 prepared in topic 2.1. The synthesis was performed in different molar ratios: 51/49, 76/24, 84/16, and 88/12 by wet-kneading methodology in a ball milling using zirconia spheres. In a typical preparation, 1.0 g of solid (using the desired ratio MgO/SiO2) and 20.0 mL of distilled water were let react in the ball milling for 4 h. Then, the sample was dried at 80°C for 15 h and calcined under a flow of air (100 mL min−1) at 500°C (2°C min−1) for 4 h. The samples were named MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK, where x/y is the MgO/SiO2 molar ratio and WK stands for wet-kneading methodology. 2.2.1 Characterization of catalysts Powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku Multiflex with CuKα radiation in the continuous scanning type between 2θ of 10 and 90 º and step size of 0.02 º min−1. Surface area (BET method), average pore size (BJH method), and pore volume were determined from the isotherm obtained by nitrogen physisorption at -196°C using Micrometrics ASAP 2020 equipment. The basicity of the catalysts was measured by TPD of CO2 using MicromeriticsAutoChem II - Chemisorption Analyzer, model 2920. For the analysis, 100 mg of samples were pre-treated at 600°C under helium flow. After cooling to 40°C, the sample was exposed to a flow of CO2 (50 mL min−1) for 1 h. After that, under helium flow, the material was gradually heated to the temperature of 900°C. In this configuration, the reactor's output is connected to a Mass Spectrometer, plotting the CO2 desorption profiles according to the temperature. 2.2.2 Catalytic tests The performance of the MgO/SiO2 catalysts towards ethanol conversion was studied in a fixed-bed flow reactor. The reactor was loaded with 200 mg of catalyst and pre-treated at 600°C for 1 h under a flow of He (20 mL min−1). After colling down to the reaction temperature, ethanol was fed into the reactor by flowing He a through the ethanol saturator at 55°C. The gas composition fed to the reactor was 5.8 mL min−1 of ethanol and 10 mL min−1 of He. The catalysts were tested at 350, 375, 400, 425, and 450°C, and the reaction products were analyzed in a gas chromatograph Varian GC-3400 CX coupled to a thermal conductivity detector and using a Cromosorb-102 column. The mass and heat-transfer limitations were verified by calculating respectively the j D and j H factors from the Reynolds number [15], and the calculations confirmed that our catalytic system is only reaction limited. The ethanol conversion ( C ), product selectivities ( S p ) and forward reaction rates ( r f ) were calculated by the formulas: (1) C = ( n e t h a n o l , i n − n e t h a n o l , o u t n e t h a n o l , i n ) x 100 (2) S p = ( n p r o d u c t n e t h a n o l , i n − n e t h a n o l , o u t ) x 100 (3) r f = ( F e t h a n o l x C 100 x S p 100 ) m c Where, n is the molar flow of carbon atom, F e t h a n o l is the ethanol flux and m c is the weight of the catalyst. In parallel, the apparent activation energy for the forwarding reaction ( E a f ) was calculated by the Arrhenius equation: (4) k = A e x p − E a R T (5) l n ( r f ) = l n ( A ) − ( E a f ) R T where A is the pre-exponential factor; R is the gas constant and T is the temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 MgO/SiO2 prepared by wet-kneading In order to understand the structures of the parent silicon and magnesium oxides and the resulting mixed oxides MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK, the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and nitrogen physisorption at -196°C. As shown in A, MgO presents a typical crystalline cubic structure, while SiO2 is amorphous, displaying only the characteristic halo between 2θ of 15 and 40 °. As shown in Table 1 , the specific surface area (SBET) for silica and magnesia were 206 and 127 m2 g−1, and the pore diameters were 13 and 9 nm, respectively. The wet-kneading of silica and magnesia with different MgO/SiO2 molar ratios led to significant changes in both structural and textural properties. For instance, MgO/SiO2(51/49)-WK, the sample with the highest silica loading, did not present peaks due to crystalline magnesium oxide, while peaks assigned to layered magnesium silicate were observed. Hence, at low MgO loading, this oxide reacts with the silica surface forming primarily Mg silicates and, possibly, highly dispersed amorphous MgO that does not display XRD signals [16]. Another evidence of the structural difference between MgO/SiO2(51/49)-WK and the pure parent oxides is that MgO and SiO2 have, respectively, 3 and 5 times the surface area of this mixed oxide (Table 1). MgO/SiO2(76/24)-WK, the material with the second-highest silica loading, displays strong peaks due to hexagonal magnesium hydroxide and weak peaks assigned to Mg silicate (Fig. 2 A). Similar to the observed for MgO/SiO2(51/49)-WK, the formation of cubic magnesium oxide was hindered by the high silica loading. Compared to MgO and SiO2, MgO/SiO2(76/24)-WK presented a substantial reduction in the surface area, pore volume, and size (Table 1). MgO/SiO2(84/16)-WK and MgO/SiO2(88/12)-WK displayed XRD peaks predominantly due to cubic MgO. Magnesium silicate is also expected to be present [20], whereas it is not observed on the XRD pattern (Fig. 2A) due to the high intensity of the MgO peaks. Regarding the surface area, pore size, and pore volume, there is a general trend for the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK: these parameters increase along with the MgO molar ratio, although they are always lower than the ones observed for the pure oxides (Table 1). To verify the effect of the structural properties on the surface basicity, the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK catalysts and pure MgO were analyzed by TPD-CO2. The TPD-CO2 deconvoluted profiles are presented in Fig. 2B and the area of each deconvoluted band is presented in Table 1. Overall, 5 groups of basic sites were detected, 3 weaker (CO2 desorption below 300°C) and 2 stronger (CO2 desorption above 500°C). On one hand, pure MgO presents just basic sites that desorb CO2 at temperatures below 300°C; on the other hand, the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK catalysts present both weaker and stronger basic sites. Moreover, the CO2 uptake was at least 8.0 times higher for MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK than for MgO, which could be attributed to the formation of Mg silicate [20,21] and the presence of highly dispersed amorphous MgO on the silica surface [16]. Previous work has shown that the TPD-CO2 for MgO dispersed on silica shows intense CO2 desorption at temperatures below 300°C and between 300-750°C [16]. Similarly, Mg silicate, depending on the synthesis methodology, can present the CO2 desorption at the lower [21–23] or higher [21,23] temperature range. Therefore, although MgO has a higher surface area than MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK, the species formed in the mixed oxides allow a higher concentration of basic sites and a higher contribution of stronger basic sites that desorb CO2 at temperatures above 790°C as the MgO loading increases, representing a significant change in the surface properties. In any case, it is difficult to identify if the basic sites responsible to promote several of the reaction steps in the conversion of ethanol to butadiene are due to dispersed amorphous MgO or Mg silicate. However, it has been well established that Mg silicate is bifunctional and presents acid sites in addition to the basic sites [20,23,24]. To better understand the properties of Mg silicate, MgO/SiO2 with the evident presence of crystalline magnesium silicate phase (Fig. S1A) was prepared by sol-gel methodology with MgO/SiO2 molar ratio of 76/24 and 84/16 [MgO/SiO2(76/24)-SG and MgO/SiO2(84/16)-SG]. By TPD-CO2 (Fig. S1B), it is shown in both catalysts a notable contribution of Mg silicate with strong basic sites (CO2 desorption above 500°C). Furthermore, these catalysts convert ethanol predominantly to acetaldehyde (base-catalyzed reaction) and ethylene (acid-catalyzed reaction), and at temperatures above 425°C, ethylene becomes the major product (Fig. S2). The acidity responsive to dehydrate ethanol to ethylene cannot be attributed to silica since pure silica is significantly less active in ethylene formation (Fig. 3 ), reaching a maximum yield of 2.0 % at 450°C, much lower than the 32.8 % observed in the Mg silicate rich MgO/SiO2(76/24)-SG. MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK were studied in the conversion of ethanol, as shown in Fig. 3. MgO/SiO2(51/49)-WK was the most active catalyst reaching 96.6 % conversion at 450°C, but with the lowest selectivity to BD. Indeed, due to the predominant presence of Mg silicate (Fig. 2A), the catalyst produces ethylene as the major product (76.6 % yield at 450°C) and diethyl ether as a secondary product. The pure oxides SiO2 and MgO are also active for ethanol conversion into ethylene, but with significantly lower yield (2.0 and 6.3 %, respectively, at 450°C). Increasing the MgO contribution in MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK leads to an efficient catalyst for BD production, being MgO/SiO2(84/16)-WK the most selective (between 59.0 and 75.0 %), while MgO/SiO2(76/24)-WK and MgO/SiO2(88/12)-WK present lower but similar BD selectivities. Additionally, MgO/SiO2(88/12)-WK is significantly less active than the other catalysts. The active site for BD formation is under debate, for instance, recent studies identified different species of magnesium silicate by SS-NMR [20] and suggested that layered magnesium oxide promotes butadiene production through the Aldol Mechanism, while the amorphous magnesium silicate dehydrates ethanol to ethylene. Nevertheless, other authors suggest that magnesium silicate would not be determinant in the activity of the catalyst for ethanol conversion to butadiene through the Aldol condensation mechanism [23]. Defining the active species of the reaction is not straightforward and has been a debate, especially because literature reports Mg silicate with different structures and surface basicity [21–23]. It is well established, however, that the simple mixture of silica and magnesia is not selective to BD and, hence, the active sites shall be the ones formed in the wet-kneading processes of the oxides. An important observation from the set of data reported herein is that high BD selectivity was obtained for catalysts that presented two families of basic sites (weaker and stronger, as shown in Fig. 2B). Catalysts with only weaker [MgO and MgO/SiO2(51/49)-WK] or stronger basic sites [MgO/SiO2(x/y)-SG] displayed poor performance on ethanol conversion to BD. The reaction rates for the forward reaction ( r f ) as a function of the temperature for the main products (acetaldehyde, ethylene and BD) are shown in Fig. 3 and the apparent activation energy of the forward reaction ( E a f ) estimated from the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (5)) is presented in Table 2 . Interestingly, the E a f increases linearly with MgO loading (Table 2 and Fig. S3) indicating that an excess of magnesium oxide should hinder the reaction. The E a f for butadiene presents comparable values to the E a f for ethylene, as commonly expected for a reaction intermediate involved in the reaction determining step. Indeed, according to the Prins mechanism, ethylene would be the intermediate (Fig. 1). The reaction rates for each catalyst (Fig. 4 ) reveal that the r f for BD, differently from r f for acetaldehyde and ethylene, presented a volcano-type plot with a maximum for MgO/SiO2(84/16)-WK (545 mmol g−1 h−1 at 450°C). Furthermore, for this catalyst, the r f for acetaldehyde and ethylene was significantly lower compared to BD, reaching, respectively, 53 and 187 mmol g−1 h−1 at 450°C. Compared to the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK, MgO presented the lowest r f for all products, as a consequence of the high E a f shown in Table 2 and Fig. S3. As expected, due to the predominancy of acidic Mg silicate, MgO/SiO2(51/49)-WK displayed the highest r f for ethylene, followed by MgO/SiO2(84/16)-WK, which is active in ethylene formation, especially at high-temperature ranges. As mentioned before, acetaldehyde is an intermediate of the Aldol condensation mechanism and ethylene and acetaldehyde are intermediate of the Prins condensation mechanism, respectively. The presence of both intermediates in significant concentration would allow BD to be formed by both reaction pathways [13]. It would be meaningful, therefore, to identify which reaction pathway is predominant for the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK under the reaction conditions applied herein. 3.2 Proposed mechanism for the ethanol to 1,3-butadiene conversion in the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK catalysts Scheme 1 shows the reaction steps involved in the ethanol conversion to BD through the Aldol or Prins condensation mechanisms, in which, the condensation step was considered the rate-determining step and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism was used [25]. where DS stands for rate-determining step; y and x are basic and acidic sites, respectively; A b is the molecule A adsorbed on the site b ; Et is ethanol; AcH is acetaldehyde; Ete is ethylene; Ac is acetaldol; Cr is crotonaldehyde; Ca is crotyl alcohol; Bu is 3-buten-2-ol; BD is 1,3-butadiene; H 2 O is a molecule of water and H 2 is a molecule of hydrogen gas. (9)-(12), it is possible to correlate the rate of the forward reaction for BD ( r f B D ) with those for the products acetaldehyde and/or ethylene ( r f A c H and r f E t e , respectively) to obtain Eqs. (13) and (14). As for the Prins condensation mechanism, Eq. (14) indicates that r f B D is associated with the rate of both intermediates acetaldehyde and ethylene (expressed by r f A c H r f E t e ). Importantly, these equations disregard the adsorption terms for the reactants and products, making it possible to study reaction rates at high ethanol conversions. Moreover, the kinetic parameters of these equations are just temperature dependent, which allows the use of experimental results obtained in Fig. 4 since any reaction rate (averaged or point) would produce the same result. Thus, combining Eqs. (13) and (14) with the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (4)) leads to Eqs. (15), (16). Aldol Condensation (15) r f B D r f A c H 2 = A B D A A c H 2 e x p ( 2 E a f A c H − E a f B D ) R T Prins Condensation (16) r f B D r f A c H r f E t e = A B D A A c H A E t e e x p ( E a f A c H + E a f E t e − E a f B D ) R T Fig. 5 shows the fit of Eqs. (15), (17) using the experimental data displayed in Fig. 4. For MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK and MgO, only Eq. (16) provides the expected linear correlation (Fcalculated = 26.40 ≥ Ftheoretical = 4.35 at α = 0.05), giving direct proportionality between the forward reaction rates of BD and the products of the forward reaction rates of acetaldehyde and ethylene. This behavior suggests that the Prins condensation mechanism shall be predominant in the ethanol conversion to BD in these materials. Indeed, a previous DFT study [11] for MgO shows that the direct reaction between ethylene and acetaldehyde adsorbed on adjacent sites presents a free energy barrier as low as 29 kcal mol−1, suggesting that the Prins condensation is a feasible route. Seeking to understand the active site, additional DFT studies [26] have shown that the interaction between MgO and SiO2 leads to significant changes in the Mg-O-Mg clusters compared to bulk MgO due to the formation of Mg-O-Mg, Mg-O-Si, and Mg-O-H structures. Hence, the acidity of Mg ions is modified from strong to weak in the order of Mg-O-Mg > Mg-O-Si, and the basicity of O ions is modified from strong to weak on the order of Mg-O-Mg > Mg-O-Si > Mg-OH-Mg > Mg-OH-Si. The paired arrangement of the acid-basic conjugate sites and the strength of the acid-basic sites are determinants for dehydrogenation and dehydration of ethanol and condensation of the respective intermediates of acetaldehyde and ethylene to form 1,3-butadiene. However, as mentioned before, experimentally, it has been shown that the acidity on MgO/SiO2-type catalysts is predominantly attributed to Mg silicates, while the nature of the basic sites is under debate. In any case, from experimental and computational studies, several pieces of evidence suggest that the catalyst shall need vicinal acidic and basic sites to activate species and efficiently promote the condensation steps. Regarding the Aldol condensation reaction pathway, previous studies have suggested a direct proportionality between the rate of BD formation and the square of the rate of acetaldehyde formation (as described in Eq. 14) using MgO/SiO2 catalysts [9]. However, our experimental data does not fit linearly for Eq. (15), indicating that the Aldol condensation mechanism is not predominant (Fig. 5). Interestingly, DFT calculations [27] suggest that MgO supported on SiO2 presents strong Lewis acidity on the Mg ions and weak basicity on the O ions, favoring the balancing of the reaction barrier for aldol condensation of acetaldehyde. Although condensation is kinetically and thermodynamically feasible at Mg-O-Mg sites, the subsequent products may be strongly adsorbed and can decrease the accessibility of ethanol to these active sites. Even though it is reasonable to expect a contribution from aldol condensation in BD formation [1,7,11,12,20,27–31], our data suggest that for the catalysts prepared via wet-kneading methodology, the condensation of the intermediates of ethylene and acetaldehyde, via the Prins pathway reaction, should be predominant. 4 Conclusions The catalysts obtained by wet-kneading show structure and catalytic properties dependent on the MgO/SiO2 composition. At low MgO loading (MgO of 51 mol. %), the catalyst presented crystalline magnesium silicate on the surface of amorphous silica, showing weak basic sites and acidic sites capable of dehydrating ethanol into ethylene. Increasing the MgO loading, crystalline hexagonal magnesium hydroxide is formed, which changes to cubic magnesium oxide. These mixed oxides exhibit high activity for 1,3-butadiene formation. The best catalyst is MgO/SiO2(84/16)-WK, which presented a balance of acidic and weak and strong basic sites, showing higher ethanol conversion and selectivities to 1,3-butadiene. The MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK shows a linear correlation between r f B D and r f A c H r f E t e , indicating that Prins condensation mechanism should be predominant in this reaction, due to the presence of paired arrangement of the acid-basic conjugate sites that catalyze 1,3-butadiene formation. The acid-base force balance in magnesium silicate and MgOx layers of the MgO/SiO2(x/y)-WK catalysts determines the selectivity for acetaldehyde and ethylene formation, while their pairwise structure determines the probability of catalyzing the condensation of the intermediates of acetaldehyde and ethylene to 1,3-butadiene and determines the selectivity to 1,3-butadiene. coredata.dc:description: MgO/SiO2 catalysts prepared by wet-kneading with various compositions were applied to directly convert ethanol to 1,3-butadiene. The MgO/SiO2 molar ratio significantly affected the structural, textural, and surface properties of the catalysts, leading to different activities toward ethanol conversion. At low MgO loading (51 mol %), magnesium silicate is formed on the amorphous silica surface, resulting in a higher activity for ethanol dehydration to ethylene. Increasing the MgO loading, crystalline magnesium oxide is formed in addition to the magnesium silicate, producing strong basic sites capable of increasing the ethanol conversion to 1,3-butadiene. Interestingly, for the mixed oxides prepared herein, a linear correlation was found between the forward reaction rate for 1,3-butadiene formation as a function of the reaction rate for acetaldehyde and ethylene. This behavior suggests a predominance of the Prins condensation mechanism. Therefore, the paired arrangement and the strength of the acid-basic conjugate sites of these catalysts must be determinant for the dehydrogenation and dehydration of ethanol and the condensation of the respective intermediates acetaldehyde and ethylene to form 1,3-butadiene.
coredata.dc:title: MgO/SiO2 prepared by wet-kneading as a catalyst for ethanol conversion to 1,3-butadiene: Prins condensation as the predominant mechanism
